messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Nonlinear static isogeometric analysis of arbitrarily curved Kirchhoff-Love shells

Paper Abstract: 

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The Theory of Shells and Plates",
        "Models and Finite Elements for Thin-Walled Structures",
        "The MITC3+ shell element in geometric nonlinear analysis",
        "The MITC4+ shell element in geometric nonlinear analysis",
        "Finite rotation meshfree formulation for geometrically nonlinear analysis of flat, curved and folded shells",
        "Advanced reproducing kernel meshfree modeling of cracked curved shells for mixed-mode stress resultant intensity factors",
        "Geometrically nonlinear transient analysis of moderately thick laminated composite shallow shells with generalized differential quadrature method",
        "Geometric nonlinear analysis of prismatic shells using the semi-analytical finite strip method",
        "Geometrically nonlinear refined shell theories by Carrera Unified Formulation",
        "Isogeometric analysis: CAD, finite elements, NURBS, exact geometry and mesh refinement",
        "Isogeometric shell analysis with Kirchhoff–Love elements",
        "A large deformation, rotation-free, isogeometric shell",
        "Isogeometric Kirchhoff–Love shell formulations for general hyperelastic materials",
        "An extended isogeometric thin shell analysis based on Kirchhoff–Love theory",
        "Isogeometric shell analysis with NURBS compatible subdivision surfaces",
        "An efficient model reduction method for buckling analyses of thin shells based on IGA",
        "Isogeometric Kirchhoff–Love shell formulation for elasto-plasticity",
        "A simplified Kirchhoff–Love large deformation model for elastic shells and its effective isogeometric formulation",
        "A new rotation-free isogeometric thin shell formulation and a corresponding continuity constraint for patch boundaries",
        "Geometrically nonlinear postbuckling behavior of imperfect FG-CNTRC shells under axial compression using isogeometric analysis",
        "The bending strip method for isogeometric analysis of Kirchhoff–Love shell structures comprised of multiple patches",
        "A flexible approach for coupling NURBS patches in rotationless isogeometric analysis of Kirchhoff–Love shells",
        "Subdivision shells with exact boundary control and non-manifold geometry",
        "Arbitrary-degree T-splines for isogeometric analysis of fully nonlinear Kirchhoff–Love shells",
        "A Review of Trimming in Isogeometric Analysis: Challenges, Data Exchange and Simulation Aspects",
        "Isogeometric analysis of trimmed NURBS geometries",
        "Analysis in computer aided design: Nonlinear isogeometric B-Rep analysis of shell structures",
        "Weak Dirichlet boundary conditions for trimmed thin isogeometric shells",
        "A parameter-free variational coupling approach for trimmed isogeometric thin shells",
        "Variationally consistent isogeometric analysis of trimmed thin shells at finite deformations, based on the STEP exchange format",
        "Isogeometric shell analysis: The Reissner–Mindlin shell",
        "Implicit dynamic analysis using an isogeometric Reissner–Mindlin shell formulation",
        "Development of MITC isotropic triangular shell finite elements",
        "Isogeometric Reissner–Mindlin shell analysis with exactly calculated director vectors",
        "Isogeometric collocation for the Reissner–Mindlin shell problem",
        "Hierarchic isogeometric large rotation shell elements including linearized transverse shear parametrization",
        "Geometrically nonlinear analysis of thin-shell structures based on an isogeometric-meshfree coupling approach",
        "Constitutive models for strongly curved beams in the frame of isogeometric analysis:",
        "Rotation-free isogeometric analysis of an arbitrarily curved plane Bernoulli–Euler beam",
        "Rotation-free isogeometric dynamic analysis of an arbitrarily curved plane Bernoulli-Euler beam",
        "Linear static isogeometric analysis of an arbitrarily curved spatial Bernoulli–Euler beam",
        "On the analytical approach to the linear analysis of an arbitrarily curved spatial Bernoulli–Euler beam",
        "Classification of thin shell models deduced from the nonlinear three-dimensional elasticity. Part II : The strongly curved shells",
        "Generalized Kirchhoff-Love assumptions for thick shells: Application to thermal stresses in rectilinear tubes",
        "Finite rotation and finite strain isogeometric structural analysis (in Serbian)",
        "Computational Tensor Analysis of Shell Structures",
        "Shell analysis manual",
        "Nonlinear Finite Element Methods",
        "A discussion of stress rates in finite deformation problems",
        "Finite Element Procedures",
        "Foundations of shell theory",
        "A fast incremental/iterative solution procedure that handles “snap-through”",
        "On the arc-length and other quadratic control methods: Established, less known and new implementation procedures",
        "ABAQUS/Standard User’s Manual, Version 6.9",
        "Post-processing and visualization techniques for isogeometric analysis results",
        "Popular benchmark problems for geometric nonlinear analysis of shells",
        "A simple algorithm for obtaining nearly optimal quadrature rules for NURBS-based isogeometric analysis",
        "Blended isogeometric shells"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Nonlinear static isogeometric analysis of arbitrarily curved Kirchhoff-Love shells, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
